channel.title: Comments on: Repel DEET Numbers Game
channel.description: Intermediate in flow properties between solids and liquids; highly viscous.

item.title: By: Donald Schoengold
item.dc:creator: Donald Schoengold
item.description: Can't imagine that there is a major difference in efficacy between 98% and 100% so who cares.
item.content:encoded: Can’t imagine that there is a major difference in efficacy between 98% and 100% so who cares.

item.title: By: Steve
item.dc:creator: Steve
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2011/08/17/repel-deet-numbers-game/#comment-9636">Jack</a>.
Josh, the bottle appeared to be a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Positive_displacement_pump#Positive_displacement_pump" rel="nofollow">Positive Displacement Pump</a> style container, so I would assume there would not have been propellants.
Jack, thank you for the information, that's a very helpful explanation of the "technical" versus "relative" DEET concentrations.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Jack.

Josh, the bottle appeared to be a Positive Displacement Pump style container, so I would assume there would not have been propellants.

Jack, thank you for the information, that’s a very helpful explanation of the “technical” versus “relative” DEET concentrations.

item.title: By: Jack
item.dc:creator: Jack
item.description:
DEET is a chemical called N,N-Diethyl-m-toluamide. The technical grade that is used in repellent products is purified to about 98% pure DEET and the remainder is related compounds. These closely related compounds are repellent but they are not actually the exact chemical DEET as labeled, so they are required to mark the product with the actual percentage of true DEET. They do put 100% technical DEET in the can and are trying to get a little bit of marketing mileage out of the 2% related materials.
The reason that the Relative % Deet was removed from the label is because the US EPA instructed Repel to stop using that claim in October 2008. The EPA reviews and controls all language that is used on pesticide and repellent products.
FYI: I don't have any connection whatsoever to United Industries, I just happen to work with EPA regulatory matters.
item.content:encoded:
DEET is a chemical called N,N-Diethyl-m-toluamide. The technical grade that is used in repellent products is purified to about 98% pure DEET and the remainder is related compounds. These closely related compounds are repellent but they are not actually the exact chemical DEET as labeled, so they are required to mark the product with the actual percentage of true DEET. They do put 100% technical DEET in the can and are trying to get a little bit of marketing mileage out of the 2% related materials.

The reason that the Relative % Deet was removed from the label is because the US EPA instructed Repel to stop using that claim in October 2008. The EPA reviews and controls all language that is used on pesticide and repellent products.

FYI: I don’t have any connection whatsoever to United Industries, I just happen to work with EPA regulatory matters.

item.title: By: Josh
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.description:
Propellant? I would still say it's ok to call it 100% deet if that's the case.
Otherwise you would have to call Chicken "30% chicken" because it's 70% water.
item.content:encoded:
Propellant? I would still say it’s ok to call it 100% deet if that’s the case.

Otherwise you would have to call Chicken “30% chicken” because it’s 70% water.

item.title: By: Alan Parekh
item.dc:creator: Alan Parekh
item.description: I wonder if the 1.89% is something like the substance that is added to pressurize the can.
item.content:encoded: I wonder if the 1.89% is something like the substance that is added to pressurize the can.
